name: Endangered in the U.S. Quiz | Endangered Species | 15 Questions

questions.text: This wild canine once lived in much of the southern U.S., but today has only a tiny fragment of its former range. Attempts are being made to reintroduce it into the wild.
questions.explanation:
Red wolf.

	There are few pure red wolves left; most of the wild ones interbred with coyotes.

questions.text: This wild cat was also once a common denizen of Southern forests; now only a handful survive in the wild.
questions.explanation:
Florida panther.

	The Florida panther is a subspecies of mountain lion. The few remaining cats are so inbred that they have a very low survival rate. Attempts are being made to bolster their genetic health by breeding them with the very closely related Texas cougar.

questions.text: This is one of the few endangered hoofed mammals of the U.S.
questions.explanation:
Columbian whitetail deer.

	They live in only a few small areas in Washington and Oregon.

questions.text: The addition of this animal to the ranks of endangered and threatened species in 2000 caused great controversy in Montana, where locals feared attempts to protect it would limit trapping and logging.
questions.explanation:
Lynx.

	Decimated primarily by trapping, this wildcat undergoes periodic population swings tied to the population of its main prey, the snowshoe hare.

questions.text: This bird, to many people, symbolizes the conflict over enforcement of the Endangered Species Act.
questions.explanation:
Spotted owl.

	Do we keep our old-growth forests intact, or do we sell them off to the highest bidder so people can make money? That is at the heart of this controversy.

questions.text: This bird is far less famous than some other denizens of old-growth forest, but its plight has also played a role in ensuring protection of its home.
questions.explanation:
Marbled murrelet.

	The murrelet, a seabird that is a relative of the puffin, flies inland to nest in hollow trees in old-growth forests.

questions.text: This tiny songbird has played a mighty role in habitat protection in Southern California.
questions.explanation:
Least Bell's vireo.

	Riparian (riverside) habitats are the most threatened in the state, and such habitats are what the vireo requires to survive.

questions.text: What pesticide weakened the eggshells of seabirds and birds of prey, leading to their endangerment?
questions.explanation:
DDT.

	Although DDT is now banned in the US, it is still produced and sold for export to Third World countries.

questions.text: Now called Wildlife Services, this branch of the U.S. Department of Agriculture has poisoned, trapped, gassed and shot hundreds of thousands of predatory animals over the last century, helping extirpate almost all of the grizzlies and wolves in the continental United States.
questions.explanation:
Animal Damage Control.

	Funded by taxpayer dollars, this agency still kills tens of thousands of animals every year.

questions.text: This mammal, a denizen of prairie dog towns, is a relative of the European polecat.
questions.explanation:
Black-footed ferret.

	This wonderful mammal was almost wiped out as prairie dog towns were poisoned by Animal Damage Control and by ranchers.

questions.text: Which one of the following organizations does not work to protect endangered species?
questions.explanation:
Wildlife Legislative Fund of America.

	The WLFA is a hunting-rights lobbying organization.

questions.text: What is the primary reason that most endangered species in the U.S. have become endangered?
questions.explanation:
Habitat loss.

	No animal can live without a home...

questions.text: This large sea mammal, found mostly in Florida waters, is often injured by boat propellers.
questions.explanation:
Manatee.

	The manatee, a gentle vegetarian cousin to the elephant, gave rise to mermaid legends...those sailors must not have seen land for a LONG time!

questions.text: This beautiful tool-using mammal, found off the Pacific coast from California to Alaska, was nearly wiped out by the fur industry.
questions.explanation:
Sea otter & Otter.

	Sea otters break open shells with rocks, and wrap themselves in kelp floats while sleeping.

questions.text: What is the chief Federal legislation that protects endangered species in the U.S. called (Hint: it's mentioned in this quiz!)?
questions.correct: Endangered Species Act & the Endangered Species Act
questions.explanation: Endangered Species Act & the Endangered Species Act.
